report_title: Commercial Washing Machine Manufacturing Industry Report
executive_summary: The Commercial Washing Machine Manufacturing industry consists of manufacturers that manufacture commercial washing machines, which are most commonly used in laundromats and multifamily homes. Commercial washing machines are typically coin-operated and offer a longer life span, easier serviceability and lower incidence rate than household washing machines. Steady population growth and urbanization have failed to boost demand for commercial washing machines in the face of rising import penetration and low replacement demand.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Laundromats are the second-largest market for the Commercial Washing Machine Manufacturing industry. There are an estimated 22,421 laundromats in the United States. Overall, the Laundromats industry in the United States is expected to decline. The Dry Cleaners industry in the United States, which also provides standard washing services, is expected to shrink. The decline in these industries has weakened demand for commercial washing machines during the period.

Multifamily residential property owners and managers account for the largest share of industry revenue. Top-loading and front-loading commercial washing machines are commonly installed in apartments, condominiums and other residential structures. The multifamily residential market has expanded for most of the period with the value of residential construction increasing and rental vacancy rates declining.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Replacement Rates for Commercial Washing Machines are Cyclical
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Replacement rates for commercial washing machines are cyclical, ensuring sustained demand for commercial laundry services in residential properties. Still, this failed to translate to the Commercial Washing Machine Manufacturing industry. Overall, the industry has been subject to a period of low demand for new commercial washing machines from its largest downstream markets. As the life cycle of current commercial washing machines begins to end, industry demand is expected to be replenished.

Significant declines in export activity and simultaneous increases in import penetration have exacerbated the industry's decline. While both exports and imports have been volatile during the period, with both plummeting in 2020 amid the coronavirus pandemic, exports have consistently fallen from their 2017 high. An inflated US dollar during most of the period contributed to the decline in exports. Conversely, imports have increased, outpacing growth in industry demand and thus increasing their share of domestic demand during the period.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The urban population in the US is anticipated to increase. This growing urban population will bolster demand for laundry and professional cleaning services, translating to more demand for commercial washing machines. According to the National Multifamily Housing Council, 43.0 million households are renters with the largest demographic of renters aged 30 and under.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: THERE IS A GROWING URBAN POPULATION IN A LIMITED SPACE
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: In many major metropolitan centers, rental units are as common as homeowner units. According to the National Multifamily Housing Council, in the metropolitan area of New York-Newark-Jersey City, an estimated 26.0% of the population lives in rented apartments. The emergence of smaller apartments will underpin demand for commercial washing machines, as in-unit, residential washers and dryers are unfeasible in apartments of this size.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: ENERGY EFFICIENCY AND ENVIRONMENTAL CONCERNS WILL LIKELY BECOME MORE SIGNIFICANT FOCUSES FOR MANUFACTURERS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Demand for commercial washing machines is also driven by equipment replacement rates, which can vary depending on the investment cycle of downstream laundromat and multifamily markets. Top-loading washing machines normally last for five to eight years, while frontloading washing machines can last up to 15 years. Downstream markets will increasingly purchase equipment with enhanced functionality, ease of use and dependability, leading to higher average selling prices for manufacturers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Consumers will increasingly demand products with Energy Star certification
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Consumers will increasingly demand products with Energy Star certification and technologies that reduce water and electricity consumption. Energy Star, a joint program between the Environmental Protection Agency and Department of Energy, sets energy efficiency guidelines and certifies products that meet its criteria. Commercial washing machines that earn the Energy Star rating can be up to 37.0% more efficient than nonqualified models. These products also have inherent cost-saving advantages to multifamily property owners and managers.

industry_definition: This industry manufactures commercial washing machines. Commercial washing machines are most commonly used in laundromats and multifamily homes and are typically coin-operated. Excluded from this industry are automated or continuous tunnel washers, which are used in the textile manufacturing and healthcare markets.

threats: Low Performance Drivers: Rental vacancy rates

key_trends: Shrinking commercial markets have hurt industry performance.
Demand from both laundromats and dry cleaners has significantly declined.
The cyclical nature of the industry means that downward trends will soon reverse. Demand for washing machines will bounce back as commercial machines require replacement.
The industry is heavily regulated by both state and federal governments. Manufacturers must ensure their products meet environmental safety and energy efficiency standards.
The industry indirectly benefits from tariffs on imported goods. High tariffs on goods from China limit import penetration into the washing machine market.
Top-loaded washing machines are the industry's bread and butter. These machines' ease of use and high capacity make them perfect for laundromats and other commercial markets.

Multifamily residences like apartment buildings are the largest growing market for the industry. People living in these residences do not have the space for in-unit washers or dryers, relying instead on commercial units installed in the building's laundry room.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Multifamily residences are expected to account for the largest share of industry revenue in 2023. Multifamily residences include apartment buildings, condominiums, townhouses and other structures. Often, these buildings have on-site laundry facilities with coin- or card-operated washing machines and dryers. Building owners and property managers typically purchase new commercial washing machines to replace existing equipment or meet increased demand due to higher occupancy rates. Declining rental vacancy rates and greater concerns about energy and utility prices led to increased demand from the multifamily segment.

Laundromats are self-serve laundry facilities that house a large number of washing machines and dryers and are typically patronized by rental occupants who live in apartments without in-building laundry facilities. Laundromats purchase top-loading, frontloading, washer-extractors and stacked washing machines from the Commercial Washing Machine Manufacturing industry. Laundromats are the industry's second-largest downstream market. Rising rental rates and increasing US urbanization caused steady demand for self-serve laundromats during this period.

Hotels and motels account for significant share of this segment, as these establishments use commercial washing machines and dryers to wash bedding, towels and linens for guest use. Many large-scale hotels also offer guest laundry services, which necessitate the use of industry equipment. Hospitals and other healthcare facilities also use commercial washing machines to wash bedding and other linens. Demand from hospitals has fallen, as the COVID-19 pandemic actually discouraged consumers from visiting hospitals for nonessential and nonemergency care. Universities, athletic clubs and food establishments are also accounted for in this market segment, as these facilities often purchase large frontloading machines and washer-extractors from washing machine manufacturers. On-premise facilities often require larger, fully automated tunnel washers and laundry systems, which are outside the scope of this industry. Many of the same companies that produce commercial washing machines also produce automated laundry systems.

products_and_services.product_description: Top-load washers have doors on the top and have a general drum capacity of 3.2 to 3.3 cubic feet, which holds 15 pounds of laundry. Demand for top-load washing machines primarily depends on multifamily residential construction and rental occupancy rates, as these products are commonly installed in apartment buildings and other similar structures. Laundromats favor top-load washers over frontload varieties because they are smaller and less expensive to purchase. Top-load agitators contain a center post that rotates downwards to break down dirt during a wash and is typically the least expensive type of washing machine.

Frontload washing machines typically have a glass door on the front and a basket capacity of 2.8 to 3.1 cubic feet, slightly smaller than that of a top-load washer. Frontload washing machines typically cost more than top-load washers, but they boast the advantage of long-term energy and water savings. Since a front load washing machine uses gravity, it can submerge nearly the same amount of clothes as a top-load washer in one-third of the water. Frontload washing machines tend to be more durable than top-load machines. The accepted standard useful life of the Whirlpool Corporation's frontload washers is 10 to 15 years, compared with a useful life of between five and eight years for their top-load washers. Despite higher upfront costs, laundromats, multifamily residences and other on-premise laundering facilities increasingly opted for frontload washing machines in an effort to save on utility costs.
High-efficiency top-load washers, another type of washer, do not include a center post, and are, on average, more expensive than the top-load agitators.

Industrial Machinery & Equipment Wholesaling in the US
tier_2_buyers: Apartment & Condominium Construction in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Laundromats provide washing machines for individuals to use for a fee and are the largest downstream market for commercial washing machine manufacturers. However, over the five years to 2020, industry operators have increasingly relied on other markets, including multifamily residences and on-premise laundering facilities. Nevertheless, as laundromats expand their operations or upgrade their existing equipment, demand for commercial washing machines generally improves.

Typically, individuals and families living in urban areas have smaller homes and living spaces. As a result, these individuals are more likely to forgo in-home washing machines in favor of laundromats and professional cleaning services. This translates to demand for commercial washing machines.

Apartments and rental home tenants are more likely to use commercial laundromats. In addition, apartment owners often purchase commercial washing machines for their tenants. A decrease in rental vacancy rates normally corresponds to increased demand for commercial washing machines manufactured by this industry.

The trade-weighted index measures the strength of the US dollar against the currencies of major trading partners. When the trade-weighted index increases, it signals an appreciation of the dollar, which makes domestic goods relatively more expensive and less competitive on international markets.

The value of residential construction measures total private expenditure on single-family and multifamily structures. Increasing multifamily or apartment construction is another key determinant in commercial washing machine demand, as apartments and multifamily residences are commonly built with in-house coin- or card-operated washing machines.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Imports fell during the COVID-19 pandemic
international_trade_points.trade_description: Imports have fluctuated significantly over the past five years, falling as much as 28.7% in 2020 and increasing as much as 61.3% in 2021. The disruption to global trade caused by the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020 resulted in a decline in imports. Still, imports grew significantly as domestic demand for certain foreign-made products increased.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Major exporters to the United States
international_trade_points.trade_description: Electrolux is a widely popular washing machine company headquartered in Stockholm, Sweden and likely responsible for much of this import growth. Likewise, imports from the Czech Republic and Thailand have grown steadily through the end of 2023.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Industry exports declined during the majority of the period
international_trade_points.trade_description: The significant decline in exports is due largely to the fall in global trade in 2020 as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, which contributed to a 38.1% decline in industry exports in 2020 alone. The industry's key export destinations include Mexico and Australia, which account for an estimated 18.5% and 17.6% of industry exports, respectively.

international_trade_points.trade_title: A depreciation of the US dollar will likely spur export activity
international_trade_points.trade_description: Still, industry exports declined during the majority of the period as an inflated US dollar made foreign goods relatively less expensive compared with domestic products, encouraging import penetration into the industry. Because of the cyclical nature of demand for this industry, demand from foreign trading partners underwent a period of stagnation after a period of growth that peaked in 2017. The trade-weighted index (TWI), which measures the value of the US dollar against its trading partners, is anticipated to decline at a CAGR of 3.3% through the end of 2028. A depreciation of the US dollar coupled with a resurgence in foreign demand for washing machines will likely spur export activity for the industry once again.

business_locations.location_description: The West is home to many downstream markets and controls international trade with Pacific countries, as well as the United States' neighbors Mexico and Canada. California's sheer size, population, and control of the Pacific coast make it a popular location for manufacturers. Its shared border with Mexico also contributes to its presence in the manufacturing sector.

The Great Lakes region is the historic manufacturing backbone of the United States. Key up- and downstream markets are located in the region. Also, the region serves as the heart of the steel manufacturing industry as a whole. The Great Lakes region is home to several prominent cities whose urban populations require laundry machines. Chicago, Detroit and Milwaukee are

The Southeast region is popular among manufacturers because of its proximity to major markets and well-developed transportation infrastructure. This includes highways, airports and ports, making it easy for manufacturers to reach markets. The Southeast is home to the majority of the country's population. While much of the area is rural or residential, the sheer number of people living in the region has ensured high demand from downstream markets. Large cities such as Miami, Jacksonville and Charlotte are in this region.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Department of Energy requires that all top-loading commercial washing machines manufactured after January 2018 must have a modified energy factor (MEF) of no less than 1.4 and a water factor (WF) of no more than 8.8.

The Energy Star program, a joint venture between the Environmental Protection Agency and Department of Energy aimed at helping consumers improve their energy efficiency, sets rating guidelines for commercial washing machines. Similar to Department of Energy standards, Energy Star ratings are based on WF and MEF performance metrics. Commercial washers that earn the Energy Star rating are up to 37.0% more efficient than nonqualified models.

The Federal Trade Commission has also stipulated rules concerning disclosures of energy and water consumption by commercial washing machines. There are at least three types of standards: Safety and environmental standards, Energy-efficiency standards that set minimum efficiency requirements, often prescribed by government regulations, Test procedure standards that prescribe a method of test for determining performance characteristics and energy efficiency of commercial washing machines.
For front-loading machines, the MEF is no less than 2.0 and the WF is no greater than 4.1.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is in the decline stage of its life cycle.
The industry has high revenue volatility.
The industry receives low and steady levels of assistance.
The industry faces high and steady levels of competition.

basis_points.basis_description: Manufacturers compete on the basis of price.
Manufacturers compete on brand recognition and reputation.
Location, availability and compatibility with other appliances are important points of competition.
Imports pose the stiffest competition, with rising domestic demand share threatening domestic revenue.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The top three companies account for 60.9% of industry revenue in 2023.
Larger manufacturers benefit from name recognition, connections with markets, and ability to meet regulations.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wages have consistently been a considerable cost for manufacturers, as workers are needed to test, inspect and assemble washing machines. Highly skilled employees are required to develop products that comply with energy regulations. Declines in industry revenue have exceed declines in industry wages, which has caused wages' share of revenue to increase during the period. While automation is a persistent force in the manufacturing sectors, labor continues to expand for manufacturers. Wages may be experiencing upward pressure from the increased need for engineers and premium that employers have to pay to attract workers to manufacturing jobs. The prevalence of union membership is also expected to place upward pressure on wages. Wages' share of industry revenue has increased from 19.1% in 2018 to an estimated 20.5% in 2023.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Falling profit in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit is driven by labor and input costs and downstream demand for industry products. Industry profit has fluctuated throughout the period as wage costs and the costs of raw inputs, such as the world price of steel, have increased, putting downward pressure on profit. The COVID-19 pandemic in 2020 led to profit declines as demand for washing machines was stifled by economic uncertainty. Notable profit gains have been hampered by the increased demand for more energy-efficient products which require manufacturers to spend more on electrical components. Profit has plummeted to 3.9% of revenue in 2023, down from 6.7% in 2018.

Purchases are the industry's largest expense. Similar to many other manufacturing industries, purchases account for the largest portion of industry costs. Purchases include raw material such as aluminum, steel sheets and other steel parts. Manufacturers also commonly purchase other equipment and materials, such as generators, electrical transmission, distribution and control equipment, pipes, valves, and fittings. Purchase costs have experienced downward pressure from lower commodity prices and upward pressure from a greater need for electrical components. Overall, purchases are expected to account for 44.7% of total industry revenue in 2023.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Labor is a major cost for potential manufacturers
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The construction of washing machines requires both technical and physical skills. Also, workers are represented by a number of unions, further complicating matters for manufacturers.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: The major markets for this industry are highly concentrated
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: This implies that the market has a focus on key customer segments. This presents an opportunity for strategic entrance into lower-end markets or unserved markets for innovations to take on a disruptive trajectory.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Industry demand is dependent on economic and demographic trends like rental vacancy rates and multifamily residential construction since individuals living in cities are more likely to require laundry services. The industry also suffered from a fall in downstream demand across all markets, as commercial washing machines only need to be replaced every few years. Purchases are often cyclical, resulting in strong revenue growth in some years but not in others.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Volatility Caused by the COVID-19 Pandemic
volatility_points.volatility_description: Revenue suffered from supply chain disruptions in 2019 and 2020 as the COVID-19 pandemic broke out across China and spread globally. Total industry exports fell 38.1% in 2020 alone, contributing to a severe revenue decline.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Top-Load Washing Machines are Favored by Laundromats
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Top-load washers have doors on the top and have a general drum capacity of 3.2 to 3.3 cubic feet, which holds 15 pounds of laundry. Demand for top-load washing machines primarily depends on multifamily residential construction and rental occupancy rates, as these products are commonly installed in apartment buildings and other similar structures. Laundromats favor top-load washers over frontload varieties because they are smaller and less expensive to purchase. Top-load agitators account for the majority of top-load washing machines.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Frontload Washing Machines Help Save on Utility Costs
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Frontload washing machines typically have a glass door on the front and a basket capacity of 2.8 to 3.1 cubic feet, slightly smaller than that of a top-load washer. Frontload washing machines typically cost more than top-load washers, but they boast the advantage of long-term energy and water savings. Since a front load washing machine uses gravity, it can submerge nearly the same amount of clothes as a top-load washer in one-third of the water. Frontload washing machines tend to be more durable than top-load machines.

FAQs.question: How is your company impacted by rising imports from abroad?
FAQs.answer: Import penetration into the industry has increased through the end of 2023. Imports surged in 2021 amid a global economic recovery from the coronavirus pandemic.

FAQs.question: Have export opportunities offered an opportunity for your company?
FAQs.answer: Overall, exports have fallen significantly. The coronavirus pandemic exacerbated exports' decline in 2020.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition opportunities in locations with well-established infrastructure networks?
FAQs.answer: Acquisition activity has been low and most companies are entrenched in the market.

FAQs.question: Has your company located in proximity to its key downstream distributors to reduce shipping costs?
FAQs.answer: Most operations are in the Great Lakes or the West. This allows for connections to suppliers and export markets.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs by automating operations over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Average wage costs have been declining. However, wages as a share of revenue have increased amid stronger revenue declines.

FAQs.question: How does your company invest in technology to establish a competitive edge over your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Technology change is primarily focused on process improvement and energy efficient designs.

FAQs.question: Have you had any regulatory expenses that have significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: Department of Energy rules have mitigated profit growth.

FAQs.question: How does your company stay ahead of regulations such as energy-efficiency standards?
FAQs.answer: Companies seek Energy Star certification in order to advertise their position beyond standards.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors?
FAQs.answer: The largest operators tend to have higher margins and low-volume producers have struggled. The average industry profit has increased as industry consolidation has grown.

FAQs.question: How does your company compensate for seasonality of cash flow?
FAQs.answer: New building activity is seasonal, which affects cash flows. However, most operators have diverse customer bases.

FAQs.question: How do you keep up with the latest technology? How do you keep costs low and maintain efficiency when doing so?
FAQs.answer: Commercial washing machine manufacturers contend with competition from other manufacturers and imports. To remain competitive, industry participants must keep up with existing technology or develop their own systems.

FAQs.question: How has your intellectual property influenced revenue?
FAQs.answer: Revolutionary product designs, such as those that use significantly less water or energy, can be a significant competitive advantage.

FAQs.question: Have you had any problems with distribution or transportation in the past?
FAQs.answer: Operators that can secure contracts with a large number of distributors are better positioned to create and expand their brand name and products.

FAQs.question: How much of your revenue comes from laundromats? How often do these customers purchase replacement machines?
FAQs.answer: As laundromats expand their operations or upgrade their existing equipment, demand for commercial washing machines generally improves.

FAQs.question: How can you capitalize on a decreasing TWI? How will your exports fare? What about your imports?
FAQs.answer: When the trade-weighted index increases, it signals an appreciation of the dollar, which makes domestic goods relatively more expensive and less competitive on international markets.

FAQs.question: Have you developed energy-efficient products that can help these customers lower their utility costs?
FAQs.answer: Typically, individuals and families living in urban areas have smaller homes and living spaces. As a result, these individuals are more likely to forgo in-home washing machines in favor of laundromats and professional cleaning services. This translates to demand for commercial washing machines.
